weaknesses.headline: Cisco Talos and the FBI warn of a state-sponsored cyber espionage group linked to Russia exploiting a seven-year-old vulnerability (CVE-2018-0171) in Cisco IOS Smart Install feature. Attackers target end-of-life devices in telecommunications, higher education, and manufacturing sectors globally. Users advised to patch or disable Smart Install to prevent data theft and system compromise.

Russian hackers linked to FSB intelligence service are exploiting CVE-2018-0171 vulnerability in Cisco routers to install backdoors and steal data. The group known as Static Tundra has been active since 2018, expanding operations in recent years.

The FBI warned of Russian threat actors targeting a 7-year-old vulnerability (CVE-2018-0171) in end-of-life networking devices running Cisco Smart Install. The activity is attributed to the FSB's Center 16, tracked by the cybersecurity industry as 'Berserk Bear' or 'Dragonfly.' The actors collected configuration files for thousands of networking devices associated with US entities across critical infrastructure sectors.

The FBI warned that threat actors tied to Russia's Federal Security Service are targeting a 7-year-old vulnerability (CVE-2018-0171) in end-of-life networking devices running Cisco Smart Install. The activity is attributed to the FSB's Center 16, tracked by the cybersecurity industry as 'Berserk Bear' or 'Dragonfly.' The actors collected configuration files for thousands of networking devices associated with US entities across critical infrastructure sectors.

Cisco and the FBI have asked 'the public, private sector, and international community'—also known as 'anyone willing to listen'—to patch their stupid end-of-life Cisco routers for an ancient 2018 vulnerability that's being 'broadly' exploited by Russian hackers linked to the country's FSB intelligence service. A group known as Static Tundra has been abusing a bug tracked as CVE-2018-0171 over the past year to install backdoors on old and outdated Cisco routers that are still haunting many corporate and government networks.

Russian hackers exploiting a seven-year-old vulnerability (CVE-2018-0171) in unpatched Cisco networking devices to target enterprise and critical infrastructure networks in the U.S. and abroad. Threat actor identified as Static Tundra targeting organizations of strategic interest to the Kremlin. (CVE-2018-0171)

Fortinet published a security advisory urging users to patch FortiSIEM to fix a critical vulnerability affecting versions 7.3.0 through 7.3.1, 7.2.0 through 7.2.5, 7.1.0 through 7.1.7, 7.0.0 through 7.0.3, and before 6.7.9. CVE-2025-25256, CVSS score 9.8, allows an unauthenticated attacker to execute unauthorized code or commands using crafted command-line interface requests. Practical exploit code found in the wild. Fortinet customers must upgrade to a fixed version, with a possible workaround of limiting access to the phMonitor port (7900).
